video.title: Day in the life of a freelance developer and mom
video.description:
Colleen is a mother of three and freelance developer. She shares freelance tips while showing what a normal day is like for her.

🐦 Colleen Schnettler on Twitter: https://twitter.com/leenyburger

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.text: Why not charge by project, instead of by the hour? Less tracking, more consistency, and you aren’t penalized if you’re a fast and proficient developer.

I have quite a fundamental question - on such days, what /when do you fit in cleanup/ food prep.? It doesn't seem like you have much time
If you are taking breaks of 5 mins each half hour  on a 9 hour day, you are basically recessing for a total of 1.5 hrs each day?

topLevelComment.author: Debbie isaacs
topLevelComment.text:
Your kids are adorable :)
Thanks so much for sharing. One of the main reasons that I wanted to start with web dev is the option to freelance as things get advanced, so that I could be a stay at home mom, please G-d.

topLevelComment.author: Michael G
topLevelComment.text: Did you learn coding on your own? Or do you have a CS degree?

topLevelComment.author: sieve5
topLevelComment.text: Instead of charging by the hour, I have started charging based on the value of my work to the client. So if the client stands to get their first round of funding for 100k, I charge them 10k (.5k for initial meeting, roadmap for sprints/project, contract. 1.5k for the next sprint based on difficulty it might be more,  keep billing until you reach the end of the project). Knowing your clients budget and what value they get out of it helps me find the value for the client even if all they have is a thousand bucks.

replies.author: sieve5
replies.text: Usually I get push-back from the client about this and we end up agreeing on a weekly or bi-weekly payments. Not charging based on a unit of time helps the client feel at ease knowing that I'm not gonna rack up a bunch of hours without them knowing what's going on.

topLevelComment.author: Shannon Clark
topLevelComment.text: That was really interesting. I’m curious: how much time do you spend maintaining existing web apps vs working on new projects for clients? Obviously I’m not familiar with your situation, but would value-based pricing be an option? That way you aren’t trading time for money, and you might be able to break for lunch, and take time off when you want to.

replies.author: sieve5
replies.text: Fun fact it was a free code camp meetup

replies.author: sieve5
replies.text: Vincent, I would hit up your local programming meetups to find some business contacts you can do freelance work for. One way I was able to get clients is by speaking on how to get started with React at my local javascript startup. This puts me in a light that showcases myself as a professional. I got two clients from that talk.
